newsitem.title: CHINA: Veteran Chinese leader Peng Zhen dies at 95 - Xinhua.
newsitem.headline: Veteran Chinese leader Peng Zhen dies at 95 - Xinhua.

text.p: Peng Zhen, the first senior victim of China's radical Cultural Revolution and a close associate of late paramount leader Deng Xiaoping, died on Saturday. He was 95.
The son of poor peasants from northern Shanxi province, he was China's last surviving elder statesman from the generation of the revolutionaries who swept the communists to power in 1949.
He died of illness, the Xinhua news agency said but gave no details.
China's Communist Party Central Committee and all top state bodies expressed "profound grief" at Peng's death.

An official obituary described Peng as "a great proletarian revolutionary and statesman, an outstanding activist in state affairs, a staunch Marxist and a major founder of the socialist legal system in China".

His death removes from China's political scene the highest-ranking and oldest member of the "old immortals" -- leaders renowned for their longevity -- to outlive Deng Xiaoping. Deng died on February 19, aged 92.

The influence of veteran revolutionaries such as Peng has continued to cast a shadow over their successors because of the enormous behind-the-scenes power they were able to wield for years after retiring from all official posts.
Long after Deng had disappeared from the public eye, Peng still appeared occasionally, sometimes in a wheelchair, lively, alert and a force to be reckoned with into his 90s.

Peng, once described by an adversary as "disarmingly aggressive", commanded a vast network of connections built up over years in the party hierarchy and as chairman of parliament, the National People's Congress.

Selected by Deng as head of parliament, he spearheaded creation of a real system of law to replace a centuries-old vacuum that both men blamed for the chaos of Chairman Mao Zedong's ultra-leftist 1966-76 Cultural Revolution in which they and millions of other Chinese were purged.

Party secretary and mayor of Beijing for 15 years and a close ally of then head of state Liu Shaoqi, Peng was hounded from office in June, 1966, by radicals charging he had transformed Beijing into a personal empire from which to combat Mao's policies.
He was banished to the countryside for 12 years, and returned to Beijing only after his longtime ally, Deng, returned to power in 1978.
He regained prominence in the late 1970s and was appointed chairman of the National People's Congress in 1983, a job that afforded him ample opportunity to build a powerbase.
He stepped down from parliament in April 1988 as part of Deng's drive to retire ageing communist comrades, but retained widespread influence.

He was a staunch ally of Deng, and a particularly vociferous promoter of Deng's campaign against "bourgeois liberalisation" -- Chinese jargon for Western ideas -- launched during a hardline resurgence in early 1987.

During the 1989 pro-democracy movement that sent millions of Chinese into the streets, Peng reportedly defended the Beijing leadership's decision to impose martial law. However, he appeared to take a less harsh line than his ageing colleagues against the students who demonstrated.
The motives of the students, he was reported as telling a special emergency meeting of the party Central Committee, were pure and patriotic.
Days later, Beijing leaders ordered troops and tanks to crack down on the protests, killing hundreds.
Born in 1902 into a poor peasant family in northern Shanxi province, Peng Zhen joined the Communist Party in 1923.
He is survived by several children. One of his sons, Chen Yuan, is vice governor of the central bank, the People's Bank of China, and a daughter runs a venture capital company.
